The Cooper test formula provided earlier does not require heart rate data to estimate VO2max. It relies solely on the distance covered during a 12-minute run. However, there are other methods for estimating VO2max that do incorporate heart rate data.

One such method is the Heart Rate Ratio Method, which uses the ratio of maximum heart rate to resting heart rate to estimate VO2max. The formula for estimating VO2max using the Heart Rate Ratio Method is as follows:

VO2max (ml/kg/min)=15×(HRmaxHRrest)\text{VO2max (ml/kg/min)} = 15 \times \left( \frac{\text{HRmax}}{\text{HRrest}} \right)VO2max (ml/kg/min)=15×(HRrestHRmax​)Where:

* VO2max is the maximal oxygen uptake in milliliters per kilogram per minute (ml/kg/min).
* HRmax is the maximum heart rate achieved during intense exercise, typically measured in beats per minute (bpm).
* HRrest is the resting heart rate, typically measured in beats per minute (bpm) while at rest.

To use this method, you would need to know both your maximum heart rate (HRmax) and your resting heart rate (HRrest). HRmax can be measured during a maximal exercise test, while HRrest is usually measured after waking up in the morning while still lying in bed.

Please note that all of these methods provide estimates of VO2max, and individual results may vary. Laboratory-based tests conducted by trained professionals are generally more accurate for measuring VO2max directly. However, the formulas mentioned here can be useful for tracking changes in aerobic fitness over time and for providing a general indication of fitness level.
